sentences: Pedro Ortiz Dávila (May 21, 1912 – July 8, 1986), better known as Davilita, was a popular Puerto Rican singer of boleros and patriotic songs.
section: N/A

sentences: He was the first artist to record the Rafael Hernández standard "Lamento Borincano".
section: N/A
== Life and career ==

sentences: Life and career ==
section: == Life and career ==
== Life and career == | === Early years ===

sentences: Early years =
section: == Life and career == | === Early years ===
== Life and career == | === Early years ===

sentences: Ortiz Dávila was born in Bayamón, Puerto Rico.
section: == Life and career == | === Early years ===

sentences: His parents, however, moved to New York City when he was only a child and settled down in East Harlem, which is also known as Spanish Harlem or El Barrio.
section: == Life and career == | === Early years ===

sentences: Davilita, as he became known, learned to play the guitar at a young age and entertained his family with his voice.
section: == Life and career == | === Early years ===

sentences: One of the places which Davilita frequented was Hernández Record Store in El Barrio, which was a common gathering place for young Latin musicians at the time.
section: == Life and career == | === Early years ===
== Life and career == | === With Rafael Hernández ===

sentences: With Rafael Hernández ===
section: == Life and career == | === With Rafael Hernández ===

sentences: In 1929, 17-year-old Davilita met by chance Puerto Rican composer Rafael Hernández.
section: == Life and career == | === With Rafael Hernández ===

sentences: Davilita got along with Hernández and was able to see the unfinished version of Hernández's composition "Lamento Borincano".
section: == Life and career == | === With Rafael Hernández ===

sentences: Davilita asked Hernández if he could record the song but Hernández thought that he was too young and declined his request.
section: == Life and career == | === With Rafael Hernández ===

sentences: The song was to be recorded by Ramón Quiroz with Davilita and Fausto Delgado as background singers but fate had a different plan.
section: == Life and career == | === With Rafael Hernández ===

sentences: Quiroz became ill on the day of the recording and Davilita ended up doing the recording as the lead voice.
section: == Life and career == | === With Rafael Hernández ===

sentences: The recording was made in 1930 with Manuel Jiménez, better known as "Canario", and his band.
section: == Life and career == | === With Rafael Hernández ===

sentences: Said recording marks the start of Davilita's career.
section: == Life and career == | === With Rafael Hernández ===

sentences: Eventually, he would join Rafael Hernández's Cuarteto Victoria.
section: == Life and career == | === With Rafael Hernández ===
== Life and career == | === With Pedro Flores ===

sentences: With Pedro Flores ===
section: == Life and career == | === With Pedro Flores ===

sentences: Davilita became very popular in the New York Latin scene and was soon working with many Latin artists.
section: == Life and career == | === With Pedro Flores ===

sentences: It wasn't long before he met Pedro Flores, a fellow Puerto Rican and composer.
section: == Life and career == | === With Pedro Flores ===

sentences: He was asked by Flores to join his group (variously known as Cuarteto Flores and Sexteto Flores), along with Myrta Silva and Daniel Santos.
section: == Life and career == | === With Pedro Flores ===

sentences: Davilita was a follower of the Puerto Rican Nationalist Party and the ideals of its president Pedro Albizu Campos.
section: == Life and career == | === With Pedro Flores ===

sentences: Together with Santos, he recorded various songs which advocated Puerto Rico's independence.
section: == Life and career == | === With Pedro Flores ===

sentences: They recorded "Patriotas" (Patriots) and "La Lucha por la Independencia de Puerto Rico" (The Fight for Puerto Rico's Independence), which was adapted from one of Juan Antonio Corretjer's poems.
section: == Life and career == | === With Pedro Flores ===

sentences: Davilita became the lead singer on many of Flores' boleros.
section: == Life and career == | === With Pedro Flores ===

sentences: He traveled to many countries with the sextet.
section: == Life and career == | === With Pedro Flores ===

sentences: Later on, Davilita formed his own band, Conjunto La Plata.
section: == Life and career == | === With Pedro Flores ===
== Life and career == | === Further collaborations ===

sentences: Further collaborations =
section: == Life and career == | === Further collaborations ===
== Life and career == | === Further collaborations ===

sentences: In 1954, Davilita had returned to Puerto Rico where he joined Felipe "La Voz" Rodríguez and together they formed a duo.
section: == Life and career == | === Further collaborations ===

sentences: Even though Davilita's voice wasn't as sharp as when he was younger, they were able to score many hits.
section: == Life and career == | === Further collaborations ===

sentences: The duo was successful in Puerto Rico, the United States and Latin America.
section: == Life and career == | === Further collaborations ===

sentences: In the 1960s, they, together with Rafael Cortijo and El Gran Combo, were able to successfully confront the wave of rock music invading the island.
section: == Life and career == | === Further collaborations ===

sentences: In 1973, Davilita and Felipe recorded Canciones de Pedro Flores (Songs of Pedro Flores) and in 1974 they recorded Canciones de Rafael Hernández (Songs of Rafael Hernández).
section: == Life and career == | === Further collaborations ===

sentences: Also in 1974, Davilita, Felipe and Pellín Rodríguez (no relation to Felipe) recorded a trilogy which are considered Puerto Rican classics.
section: == Life and career == | === Further collaborations ===

sentences: These were La Protesta de los Reyes (The Protest of the Magi), Parranda parrandera and Navidad (Christmas).
section: == Life and career == | === Further collaborations ===
== Life and career == | === Later years and death ===

sentences: Later years and death
section: == Life and career == | === Later years and death ===
== Life and career == | === Later years and death ===

sentences: On many occasions, Davilita, a strong supporter of the cause of Puerto Rican independence, stated that he was discriminated against for this reason, to the point of endangering his livelihood when the singing contracts decreased during the late 1950s and early 1960s.
section: == Life and career == | === Later years and death ===

sentences: He recorded an album of Puerto Rican patriotic standards with Mario Hernández y el Sexteto Borinquen in the early 1970s, including the songs "El Bambú", "Preciosa'" (using the original lyrics that allude to the United States as a tyrant because of its colonial control of Puerto Rico), "Mi Patria Tiembla" (the latter two composed by Rafael Hernández), "Borinquen" (a Pedro Flores work), "Los Tres Patriotas" (a composition by Davilita) and the title track "Mi Gran Bandera" (the lyrics are taken from a poem by the Puerto Rican patriot José de Diego).
section: == Life and career == | === Later years and death ===

sentences: From this same period is Davilita's recording of another patriotic song, "El Yunque y El Cordero", also with Mario Hernández y el Sexteto Borinquen.
section: == Life and career == | === Later years and death ===

sentences: Davilita had recorded over 3,000 songs before his death in Bayamón, Puerto Rico on July 8, 1986.
section: == Life and career == | === Later years and death ===

sentences: He is buried in the Braulio Dueño Colón cemetery in Bayamón.
section: == Life and career == | === Later years and death ===
